pull.title: build: Windows SSP roundup
pull.body:
I was expecting this to fail to compile somewhere, maybe in the CI, but that doesn't seem to be the case? 
Seems workable given the SSP related changes in the newer mingw-w64 headers (which are in Guix):
> Implement some of the stack protector functions/variables so -lssp is now optional when _FORTIFY_SOURCE or -fstack-protector-strong is used.

However I think this would still be broken in some older environments, so we might have to wait for a compiler bump, or similar. The optional -lssp also seems to work when using older headers, which doesn't make sense.

Guix build (aarch64)
```bash

```

Would fix #28104.

> I was expecting this to fail to compile somewhere, maybe in the CI, but that doesn't seem to be the case? Seems workable given the SSP related changes in the newer mingw-w64 headers (which are in Guix):
> 
> > Implement some of the stack protector functions/variables so -lssp is now optional when _FORTIFY_SOURCE or -fstack-protector-strong is used.

Where is this quote from?

> Where is this quote from?

The Mingw-w64 release notes: https://sourceforge.net/p/mingw-w64/mailman/message/37837156/.

issue.title: cmake: Build `libbitcoinconsensus` library
issue.body:
New CMake variables that affect the build system configuration:
- `BUILD_BITCOINCONSENSUS_LIB` (Bitcoin Core specific)
- `BUILD_SHARED_LIBS` (see CMake [docs](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/variable/BUILD_SHARED_LIBS.html))

This PR uses the same approach as the secp256k1 repo [does](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1230), which differs from the current one in the master branch.

Also see:
- https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/pull/32#discussion_r1366094140
- https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1113#discussion_r1128702492

guix: default ssp & pie for Windows GCC

events.message: guix: default ssp & pie for Windows GCC

events.body:
Concept ACK
[This comment](https://github.com/mesonbuild/meson/issues/10673#issuecomment-1243061073 ) (and the rest of that thread) helped me to understand what was going on here. As I understand it, "-lssp" should've never been needed. It was used as a hack for years, but is no longer required after mingw-w64 v11.

I'm confused like @fanquake though. I would have expected us to need to carry the hack for a while, considering that the fix is from this year.
Approach ACK on stack smashing protection stuff.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -485,12 +485,9 @@ inspecting signatures in Mach-O binaries.")
           `(append ,flags
             ;; https://gcc.gnu.org/install/configure.html
             (list "--enable-threads=posix",
-                  building-on)))
-        ((#:make-flags flags)
-          ;; Uses the SSP functions from glibc instead of from libssp.so.
-          ;; Our 'symbol-check' script will complain if we link against libssp.so,
-          ;; and thus will ensure that this works properly.
-          `(cons "gcc_cv_libc_provides_ssp=yes" ,flags))))))
+                  "--enable-default-ssp=yes",
+                  "--enable-default-pie=yes",
comments.body: How does this affect binaries? Aren't position independent executables an ELF thing, not PE?
